text: How doth the city remain solitary that was full of people? she is as a widow: she that was great among the nations, and princess among the provinces, is made tributary.
speaker: Narrator

text: She weepeth continually in the night, and her tears run down by her cheeks: among all her lovers, she hath none to comfort her: all her friends have dealt unfaithfully with her, and are her enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah is carried away captive, because of affliction, and because of great servitude, she dwelleth among the heathen, and findeth no rest: all her persecutors took her in the straits.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ways of Zion lament, because no man comethto the solemn feasts, all her gates are desolate: her Priests sigh: her virgins are discomfited, and she is in heaviness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her adversaries are the chief, and her enemies prosper: for the Lord hath afflicted her, for the multitude of her transgressions, and her children are gone into captivity before the enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text: And from the daughter of Zion all her beauty is departed: her princes are become like harts that find no pasture, and they are gone without strength before the pursuer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jerusalem remembered the days of her affliction, and of her rebellion, and all her pleasant things that she had in times past, when her people fell into the hand of the enemy, and none did help her: the adversary saw her, and did mock at her Sabbaths.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jerusalem hath grievously sinned, therefore she is in derision: all that honored her, despise her, because they have seen her filthiness: yea, she sigheth, and turneth backward.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her filthiness is in her skirts: she remembered not her last end, therefore she came down wonderfully: she had no comforter: O Lord, behold mine affliction: for the enemy is proud.
speaker: Narrator

text: The enemy hath stretched out his hand upon all her pleasant things: for she hath seen the heathen enter into her Sanctuary, whom thou didst command, that they should not enter into thy Church.
speaker: Narrator

text: All her people sigh and seek their bread: they have given their pleasant things for meat to refresh the soul: see, O Lord, and consider: for I am become vile.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have ye no regard, all ye that pass by this way? behold and see, if there be any sorrow like unto my sorrow, which is done unto me wherewith the Lord hath afflicted me in the day of his fierce wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text: From above hath he sent fire into my bones, which prevail against them: he hath spread a net for my feet, and turned me back: he hath made me desolate, and daily in heaviness.
speaker: Narrator

text: The yoke of my transgressions is bound upon his hand: they are wrapped, and come up upon my neck: he hath made my strength to fall: the Lord hath delivered me into their hands, neither am I able to rise up.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hath trodden under foot all my valiant men in the midst of me: he hath called an assembly against me to destroy my young men: the Lord hath trodden the winepress upon the virgin the daughter of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: For these things I weep: mine eye, even mine eye casteth out water, because the comforter that should refresh my soul, is far from me: my children are desolate, because the enemy prevailed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zion stretcheth out her hands, and there is none to comfort her: the Lord hath appointed the enemies of Jacob round about him: Jerusalem is as a menstruous woman in the midst of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord is righteous: for I have rebelled against his commandment: hear, I pray you, all people, and behold my sorrow: my virgins and my young men are gone into captivity.
speaker: Narrator

text: I called for my lovers, but they deceived me: my Priests and mine Elders perished in the city, while they sought their meat to refresh their souls.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, O Lord, how I am troubled: my bowels swell: mine heart is turned within me, for I am full of heaviness: the sword spoileth abroad, as death doeth at home.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have heard that I mourn, but there is none to comfort me: all mine enemies have heard of my trouble, and are glad, that thou hast done it: thou wilt bring the day, that thou hast pronounced, and they shall be like unto me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let all their wickedness come before thee: do unto them, as thou hast done unto me, for all my transgressions: for my sighs are many, and mine heart is heavy.
speaker: Narrator

text: How hath the Lord darkened the daughter of Zion in his wrath! and hath cast down from heaven unto the earth the beauty of Israel, and remembered not his footstool in the day of his wrath!
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hath destroyed all the habitations of Jacob, and not spared: he hath thrown down in his wrath the strongholds of the daughter of Judah: he hath cast them down to the ground: he hath polluted the kingdom and the princes thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath cut off in his fierce wrath all the horn of Israel: he hath drawn back his right hand from before the enemy, and there was kindled in Jacob like a flame of fire, which devoured round about.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath bent his bow like an enemy: his right hand was stretched up as an adversary, and slew all that was pleasant to the eye in the Tabernacle of the daughter of Zion: he poured out his wrath like fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was as an enemy: he hath devoured Israel and consumed all his palaces: he hath destroyed his strongholds, and hath increased in the daughter of Judah lamentation and mourning.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he hath destroyed his Tabernacle, as a garden he hath destroyed his Congregation: the Lord hath caused the feasts and Sabbaths to be forgotten in Zion, and hath despised in the indignation of his wrath, the King and the Priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hath forsaken his altar: he hath abhorred his Sanctuary: he hath given into the hand of the enemy the walls of her palaces: they have made a noise in the House of the Lord, as in the day of solemnity.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hath determined to destroy the wall of the daughter of Zion: he stretched out a line: he hath not withdrawn his hand from destroying: therefore he made the rampart, and the wall to lament: they were destroyed together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her gates are sunk to the ground: he hath destroyed and broken her bars: her King and her Princes are among the Gentiles: the Law is no more, neither can her Prophets receive any vision from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Elders of the daughter of Zion sit upon the ground, and keep silence: they have cast up dust upon their heads: they have girded themselves with sackcloth: the virgins of Jerusalem hang down their heads to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mine eyes do fail with tears: my bowels swell: my liver is poured upon the earth, for the destruction of the daughter of my people, because the children and sucklings swoon in the streets of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have said to their mothers, Where is bread and drink? when they swooned as the wounded in the streets of the city, and when they gave up the ghost in their mother’s bosom.
speaker: Narrator

text: What thing shall I take to witness for thee? What thing shall I compare to thee, O daughter Jerusalem? what shall I liken to thee, that I may comfort thee, O virgin daughter Zion? for thy breach is great like the sea: who can heal thee?
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy Prophets havelooked out vain and foolish things for thee, and they have not discovered thine iniquity, to turn away thy captivity, but have looked out for thee false prophecies, and causes of banishment.
speaker: Narrator

text: All that pass by the way, clap their hands at thee: they hiss and wag their head upon the daughter Jerusalem, saying, Is this the city that men call, The perfection of beauty, and the joy of the whole earth?
speaker: Narrator

text: All thine enemies have opened their mouth against thee: they hiss and gnash the teeth, saying, Let us devour it: certainly this is the day that we looked for: we have found and seen it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hath done that which he had purposed: he hath fulfilled his word that he had determined of old time: he hath thrown down, and not spared: he hath caused thine enemy to rejoice over thee, and set up the horn of thine adversaries.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their heart cried unto the Lord, O wall of the daughter Zion, let tears run down like a river, day and night: take thee no rest, neither let the apple of thine eye cease.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arise, cry in the night: in the beginning of the watches, pour out thine heart like water before the face of the Lord: lift up thine hands toward him for the life of thy young children, that faint for hunger in the corners of all the streets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, O Lord, and consider to whom thou hast done thus: shall the women eat their fruit, and children of a span long? shall the Priest and the Prophet be slain in the Sanctuary of the Lord?
speaker: Narrator

text: The young and the old lie on the ground in the streets: my virgins and my young men are fallen by the sword: thou hast slain them in the day of thy wrath: thou hast killed, and not spared.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast called as in a solemn day my terrors round about, so that in the day of the Lord’s wrath none escaped nor remained: those that I have nourished and brought up, hath mine enemy consumed.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the man that hath seen affliction in the rod of his indignation.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath led me, and brought me into darkness, but not to light.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely he is turned against me: he turneth his hand against me all the day.
speaker: Narrator

text: My flesh and my skin hath he caused to wax old, and he hath broken my bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath built against me, and compassed me with gall and labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath set me in dark places, as they that be dead forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath hedged about me, that I cannot get out: he hath made my chains heavy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also when I cry and shout, he shutteth out my prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath stopped up my ways with hewn stone, and turned away my paths.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was unto me as a bear lying in wait, and as a lion in secret places.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath stopped my ways, and pulled me in pieces: he hath made me desolate.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath bent his bow, and made me a mark for the arrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: He caused the arrows of his quiver to enter into my reins.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was a derision to all my people, and their song all the day.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath filled me with bitterness, and made me drunken with wormwood.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath also broken my teeth with stones, and hath covered me with ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus my soul was far off from peace: I forgot prosperity,
speaker: Narrator

text: And I said, My strength and my hope is perished from the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: Remembering mine affliction, and my mourning, the wormwood and the gall.
speaker: Narrator

text: My soul hath them in remembrance, and is humbled in me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I consider this in mine heart: therefore have I hope.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is the Lord’s mercies that we are not consumed, because his compassions fail not.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are renewed every morning: great is thy faithfulness.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord is my portion, saith my soul: therefore will I hope in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord is good unto them that trust in him, and to the soul that seeketh him.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is good both to trust, and to wait for the salvation of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is good for a man that he bear the yoke in his youth.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sitteth alone, and keepeth silence, because he hath borne it upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He putteth his mouth in the dust, if there may be hope.
speaker: Narrator

text: He giveth his cheek to him that smiteth him: he is filled full with reproaches.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord will not forsake forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: But though he send affliction, yet will he have compassion according to the multitude of his mercies.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he doth not punish willingly, nor afflict the children of men,
speaker: Narrator

text: In stamping under his feet all the prisoners of the earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: In overthrowing the right of a man before the face of the most High,
speaker: Narrator

text: In subverting a man in his cause: the Lord seeth it not.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is he then that saith, and it cometh to pass, and the Lord commandeth it not?
speaker: Narrator

text: Out of the mouth of the most High proceedeth not evil and good?
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherefore then is the living man sorrowful? man suffereth for his sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us search and try our ways, and turn again to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us lift up our hearts with our hands unto God in the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have sinned, and have rebelled, therefore thou hast not spared.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast covered us with wrath, and persecuted us: thou hast slain, and not spared.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast covered thyself with a cloud, that our prayer should not pass through.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast made us as the offscouring and refuse in the midst of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: All our enemies have opened their mouth against us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fear, and a snare is come upon us with desolation and destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mine eye casteth out rivers of water, for the destruction of the daughter of my people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mine eye droppeth without stay, and ceaseth not,
speaker: Narrator

text: Till the Lord look down, and behold from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mine eye breaketh mine heart because of all the daughters of my city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mine enemies chased me sore, like a bird, without cause.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have shut up my lifein the dungeon, and cast a stone upon me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Waters flowed over mine head, then thought I, I am destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: I called upon thy Name, O Lord, out of the low dungeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast heard my voice: stop not thine ear from my sigh, and from my cry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou drewest near in the day that I called upon thee: thou saidest, Fear not.
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord, thou hast maintained the cause of my soul, and hast redeemed my life.
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord, thou hast seen my wrong, judge thou my cause.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast seen all their vengeance, and all their devises against me:
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast heard their reproach, O Lord, and all their imaginations against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lips also of those that rose against me, and their whispering against me continually.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, their sitting down, and their rising up, how I am their song.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give them a recompense, O Lord, according to the work of their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give them sorrow of heart even thy curse to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Persecute with wrath and destroy them from under the heaven, O Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: How is the gold become so dim? the most fine gold is changed, and the stones of the Sanctuary are scattered in the corner of every street.
speaker: Narrator

text: The noble men of Zion comparable to fine gold, how are they esteemed as earthen pitchers, even the work of the hands of the potter!
speaker: Narrator

text: Even the dragons draw out the breasts, and give suck to their young: but the daughter of my people is become cruel like the ostriches in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tongue of the sucking child cleaveth to the roof of his mouth for thirst: the young children ask bread, but no man breaketh it unto them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They that did feed delicately, perish in the streets: they that were brought up in scarlet, embrace the dung.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the iniquity of the daughter of my people is become greater than the sin of Sodom, that was destroyed as in a moment, and none pitched camps against her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her Nazirites were purer than the snow, and whiter than the milk: they were more ruddy in body, than the red precious stones: they were like polished sapphire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now their visage is blacker than a coal: they cannot know them in the streets: their skin cleaveth to their bones: it is withered like a stock.
speaker: Narrator

text: They that be slain with the sword, are better than they that are killed with hunger: for they fade away as they were stricken through for the fruits of the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hands of the pitiful women have sodden their own children, which were their meat in the destruction of the daughter of my people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hath accomplished his indignation: he hath poured out his fierce wrath, he hath kindled a fire in Zion, which hath devoured the foundations thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text: The kings of the earth, and all the inhabitants of the world would not have believed that the adversary and the enemy should have entered into the gates of Jerusalem:
speaker: Narrator

text: For the sins of her prophets, and the iniquities of her priests, that have shed the blood of the just in the midst of her.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have wandered as blind menin the streets, and they were polluted with blood, so thatthey would not touch their garments.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they cried unto them, Depart ye polluted, depart, depart, touch not: therefore they fled away, and wandered: they have said among the heathen, They shall no more dwell there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The anger of the Lord hath scattered them, he will no more regard them: they reverenced not the face of the Priest, nor had compassion on the Elders.
speaker: Narrator

text: While we waited for our vain help, our eyes failed: for in our waiting we looked for a nation that could not save us.
speaker: Narrator

text: They hunt our steps, that we cannot go in our streets: our end is near, our days are fulfilled, for our end is come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our persecutors are swifter than the eagles of the heaven: they pursued us upon the mountains, and laid wait for us in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: The breath of our nostrils, the Anointed of the Lord was taken in their nets, of whom we said, Under his shadow we shall be preserved alive among the heathen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rejoice and be glad, O daughter Edom: that dwellest in the land of Uz, the cup also shall pass through unto thee: thou shalt be drunken and vomit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy punishment is accomplished, O daughter Zion: he will no more carry thee away into captivity, but he will visit thine iniquity, O daughter Edom, he will discover thy sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember, O Lord, what is come upon us: consider, and behold our reproach.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our inheritance is turned to the strangers, our houses to the aliens.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are fatherless, even without father, and our mothers are as widows.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have drunk our water for money, and our wood is sold unto us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our necks are under persecution: we are weary, and have no rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have given our hands to the Egyptians, and to Assyria, to be satisfied with bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our fathers have sinned, and are not, and we have borne their iniquities.
speaker: Narrator

text: Servants have ruled over us, none would deliver us out of their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: We got our bread with the peril of our lives, because of the sword of the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our skin was black like as an oven because of the terrible famine.
speaker: Narrator

text: They defiled the women in Zion, and the maids in the cities of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The princes are hanged up by their hand: the faces of the Elders were not had in honor.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took the young men to grind, and the children fell under the wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Elders have ceased from the gate and the young men from their songs.
speaker: Narrator

text: The joy of our heart is gone, our dance is turned into mourning.
speaker: Narrator

text: The crown of our head is fallen: woe now unto us, that we have sinned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore our heart is heavy for these things, our eyes are dim,
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of the mountain of Zion, which is desolate: the foxes run upon it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But thou, O Lord, remainest forever: thy throne is from generation to generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherefore dost thou forget us forever, and forsake us so long time?
speaker: Narrator

text: Turn thou us unto thee, O Lord, and we shall be turned: renew our days as of old.
speaker: Narrator

text: But thou hast utterly rejected us: thou art exceedingly angry against us.
speaker: Narrator
